title: Thursday, 22nd November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Hey, what about those markets? They sure do go up and down, eh?

Tony Scott morning all
BE11:07am

(This is ML, FTA's thing with the whatnot.)

Are we there yet Thats about it then?
BE11:07am

And it's a Brexit/sterling day.

VV75 morning

11:07 am
BE11:07am

FTSE off 1.5% at pixel as the pound heads for its best day in ...... oh, nearly a month.

VV75 housebuilders having a good morning since the draft text
BE11:08am

Britain and the EU are to develop an “ambitious, broad, deep and flexible partnership” that will include everything from extensive trade liberalisation to “operational co-operation” between police forces, according to a leaked declaration on future relations that is due to be approved at a summit on Sunday.

Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission president, have provisionally agreed the bulk of a 26-page text that will form the final part of a Britain’s exit package from the EU. The draft falls short of the British prime minister’s aspirations for “frictionless” trade in goods with the EU after Brexit, but its ambitious tone will offer Mrs May significant help in Westminster as she prepares to sell the Brexit deal.

BE11:08am

That's our story: https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

Grouchmonkey Morning
11:09 am
BE11:09am

£ is $1.289 live.

BE11:09am

“While it cannot amount to the rights or obligations of membership, the Parties are agreed that the future relationship should be approached with high ambition with regard to its scope and depth, and recognise that this might evolve over time”, the draft says.

“Above all, it should be a relationship that will work in the interests of citizens of the Union and the United Kingdom, now and in the future.”

And you're expecting the usual response from the Brexiteers (who, as we know, managed to bounce Cameron into calling a referendum on fear of a leadership challenge yet can't even get enough letters together to raise a leadership challenge against May).

GBKrona Important as all the treaty is doing is protecting goods free trade (in the interest of EU countries, as we are a net importer), but nothing for Fin Services (we are a net exporter).
cheeckychappy Is the "leaked" draft actually being leaked by spinners for No 10 to manage expectations down so that when they come up with a better draft everybody is very pleased?
SoS didn't half leak quickly
red EU should not make the same mistake as they did with letting Cameron go back emptyhanded. the referendum can be blamed on the EU in that respect.

cheeckychappy It's called expectation management in PR, I think?

And it's a Thursday, so it must be a Centrica profit warning.

Pharma @wayneJ, no you are not correct. The EU imposed Europe-wide quotas on fishing rights that would otherwise have been 100% UK controlled under maritime law.

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 134.50, down 11.25 (-7.72%), High: 136.50, Low: 131.90, Volume: 27.72m

This one's on the supply side.

BE11:16am

Their nuclear fleet keeps switching itself off and they're not getting enough gas out of the ground, so 2018's going to be below.

wayneJ But did the UK fishermen then sell their quotas on?
11:17 am

And they're having to rejig their hedging for the UK retail price cap so 2019's going to be below as well.

The most interesting bit of it, arguably, is that it pulls 2018 EPS below the 2018 dividend.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

11.5p vs 12p.

wayneJ So - is the issue that the UK fleet underinvested? (Reminders of the UK car industry in olden times?)
Forester Still even with Brexit there are going to big arguments AMONGST UK fishermen - e.g. the Devon fishemen who fish in France.
wayneJ The Guardian - see https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jun/11/brexit-uk-fishermen-fishing-industry-quotas-uk-government - has an interesting sentence - 'One super-trawler, British-flagged but ultimately Dutch-owned, has the right to catch 94% of the English herring quota in the Atlantic and North Sea.'
PeterC BKG ... Guardian story?
BE11:19am

"Psychologically relevant," says Kepler, as if earnings didn't have any more than a psychological relationship with shareholder returns.

BE11:20am

Adjusted operating cash flow for the year is seen at between GBP2.1-2.3bn (KECH: GBP2.2bn), with net debt of GBP2.5-3.0bn (GBP2.6bn), DPS of 12.0p (12.0p), and adjusted operating profit and EBITDA above 2017 levels (ditto). Due to a higher tax rate (changed mix within E&P), the adjusted EPS of around 11.5p disappoints (13.9p). That is, 11.5p is a psychologically relevant figure as the DPS is at 12p, i.e. now above EPS. The impact from the default tariff price cap will be 3.5m x GBP68 = GBP238m for UK Home, in line with our earlier expectations. 2019E will see a GBP70m one-off charge, but with some GBP100m in cost-cuttingefforts against it. 2020E is expected to see a similar cost-cutting figure, i.e. expected cost savings would broadly offset the price cap impact by 2020E. The impact of the suspension of UK capacity payments will be around GBP50m next year and in 2020E for the group’s nuclear, batteries, andgas-fired capacities .... Against that, E&P is expected to see higher ARPUs, and thus our operating modelling seems safe for the nearer term.

Shinshin Interesting item from the Statnett CEO in the paper today about wind now being so cheap that it is actually stimulating demand for high demand industries like smelting. Astonishing turnaround in the economics.
Timmmmmmmyyyyyy Anything on intu please on their extension today, if possible? Thank you!
11:20 am
BE11:21am

They're buyers on the idea that Centrica will work one day.

L'Hermitte Re: CNA. Would the CEO survive a second divi cut?
BE11:21am

For the longer term, retail is in trouble and although Centrica might manage to offset the price cap with cost cutting, we expect (and model for) ongoing pressure on retail over the next ten years. Centrica shares have followed a roller-coaster pattern during the year. Our 160p target price was reached in July, but the shares could not defend that level since. Our TP knows about structural pressure in retail, and that is why we have a Buy rating on the stock.

wayneJ @PeterC - very interesting - and one might speculate about what would happen if it was investigated further
casapinos Divi >eps also financially relevant?
Pharma @wayneJ, the investment level has been appropriate for the level of allowed catch. Bizarre that UK waters would be considered a common resource - why not mineral rights? (I suspect this would have been part of the deal if we had joined slightly later)
cheeckychappy It would seem the negotiations around the Intu take private are correlated to the Brexit discussions in some way. Either that or wily old Whittaker is still trying to tease out David Simon...
Shinshin So is Centrica actually in structural decline becasue the very nature of the business has changed and they've not kept up.
cheeckychappy Sorry that last comment was for the benefit of @Timmmmmmmmy
GBKrona Is it just my browser, or is the playpen on the right almost empty today?
BE11:23am

Problem with Centrica is that it's politically dangerous for it to make any money. British Gas needs to be operating at breakeven at best to stop questions being asked in Parliament.

Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 806.40, down 106.2 (-11.64%), High: 893.00, Low: 801.00, Volume: 1.83m

11:29 am
BE11:30am

So what's happened is that a senator from the President-elect's MORENA party has proposed two more mining bills, in addition to the initial nine..

BE11:30am

Bill #10 is all about mining concession agreements and indigenous communities

jaws Anything on Hills and Smith today from brokers ?
BE11:30am

Bill #11 is environment protection.

Pharma @wayneJ, recommend https://gridwatch.templar.co.uk/ to answer part of your question (we're exporting power to France at the moment, but I think that is unusual), and as a wonderful time-sink.On gas, North Sea and LNG more important in UK I think.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Bills #1 to #9 are proposing things like a 2% charge on EBITDA from Mexican mines and a 5% revenue charge for mines located in indigenous areas.

wayneJ @Pharm - thx -I like that - I suspect I will be watching it a lot from now on
BE11:32am

Thing is, none of this is from leftfield (not an intentional pun).

BE11:32am

Here's RBC.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

We think a lot of the points around mining in the recently proposed bills are largely as expected by FRES
management when we met them last at the Denver Gold Forum. Whilst Bill #10’s language on possible cancellation of mining concessions if certain clauses are contravened reads badly, we see absolutely no indication that FRES is, has been or ever will be in this situation. In fact, we would argue that the group is well positioned versus peers in terms of stakeholder relations given its long history in Mexico. The rest of Bill #10 will undoubtedly make the concession permitting process for new mines/expansions more arduous due to the requirements around consultation and impact assessments. However, we would argue this just brings Mexico more in line with other international destinations such as Canada and Australia. We would note that FRES at its San Julian mine recently permitted a water reservoir for the operation using the first-ever Indigenous consultation process in mining
in Mexico. This again demonstrates that FRES is ahead of peers and in a strong position to cope with changes if/when they come.

BE11:33am

What we think the market may be missing today is the fact that all of the FRES concessions for developments for the next 24 months are in place already. This
includes the group’s next leg of growth, the high-quality Juanicipio project. On the proposed royalty changes, the 2% EBITDA charge if applied would have a
small c. -3% reduction to our EPS forecasts. On the other proposed royalty changes and need for a fund for “human and sustainable development” we would
note FRES currently has three royalty payments (concession royalty, extraordinary and special mining royalty). Of these, one-third already goes into a
community fund. Could this satisfy the legislation? Possibly. FRES also in our experience invests highly in the local communities in the areas it mines in line
with global best practice. This will put it on a strong footing if/when negotiations are had.

BE11:33am

Stepping back from the details we would also note that the feedback from both FRES management and other Mexican mining operators has been cautiously
optimistic on AMLO’s new mines minister. It is also clear to us that there is a mixture of more extreme and more moderate politicians within AMLO and that
populist headlines and proposals are to be expected in the run-up to the Mexican budget on December 15th. We hope and expect sense to prevail in the country
and for FRES shares to recover making today’s sell-off an attractive entry point.

Pharma (just saw that site has numbers for France too. Surprising difference in power use UK vs France; ~45 vs 75, for equalish populations. Anyone know why?)
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Seems a while since we talked about Fres as deserving a sector premium because it operates in a stable, predictable, low risk jurisdiction.

BE11:34am

Morgan Stanley downgraded overnight, BTW.

BE11:35am

Fresnillo has typically traded on a premium valuation to peers, on a FCF yield in the low single digits, and currently on 1.7% on spot in 2019e. Peers under our coverage typically trade on high single digit FCF yield. However, the increasing number of bills being proposed in Mexico bears potentially negative connotations for the mining industry and thus Fresnillo. Our move to Underweight reflects the impact from any rise in mining industry risks on Fresnillo, as it currently trades on a premium valuation vs peers, in part driven by the market viewing Mexico as a favourable jurisdiction for mining. With uncertainty introduced, we see scope for a de-rating and for this premium to contract pending further clarity.

11:35 am
undefined
Tom Dalgleish The twin ironies of indigenous mining royalties is that central governments take their cut and spend it in the centres of power without a second thought for local people and that indigenous people have rarely mined anything.
Mr Ticker Cheers BE

BE11:37am

11:40 am

BE11:41am

Patience @Lemmy - many UK farms owned by norwegians who face tariff barriers getting processed fish (maybe all fish) into EU.
BE11:41am

Whilst trading clearly needs to settle and improve in
time, Mothercare has achieved much under Clive Whiley in 2018. The capital restructuring was not easy but the funds and breathing space are being put to good use with the estate materially pruned and more focus and balance emerging in the Group. We are pleased with the reduction in net debt (ND) and warmly welcome an aspiration for no bank indebtedness in CY2019. All in all we keep our FY2019 financial expectations unchanged (CPTL; £16.2m) with scope for a beat on ND if a head office sale & leaseback is completed. So, much done, much to do but the tunnel end might just be in sight.

jaws BE anything in Hils please ?
11:42 am
BE11:42am

red but not first nor will be last time we see that

undefined
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Okay, so there's a surge of demand for Hill & Smith

PeterC @BE Re: GKG Ha! understood, thanks
BE11:45am

Brace yourself for some market moving insight into the galvanizing markets.

BE11:45am

FY guidance is unchanged.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Organic revenue in the four months was up 5%, which is at the top of the recent range.

BE11:46am

And two new acquisitions, in US composites and US utilities, nudge 2019 about a percentage point higher.

BE11:46am

Here comes Investec:

Ethelred So BE what's your definition of 'Profit Warning'
11:47 am
BE11:47am

For the four months to 31 October trading has been in line with the Board’s FY18 expectations. Revenue during this period increased 12% y-o-y to £224.7m, with organic growth of 5% and a 2% FX headwind. Underlying profit in the period was ahead of the same period in FY17. The Board expects the FY18 outturn to be in line with current market expectations. Net debt at 31 October was £152.6m, up £11.4m on the 1H18, reflecting the investment in two acquisitions. The FY18 prelims results are due on 6 March 2019.

BE11:47am

In October, the UK Government announced that the
Road Investment Strategy 2 (RIS2, running 2020- 2025) programme funding would be £25.3bn, an increase of 66% on RIS1. While content on this enlarged list of programmes is difficult to predict, it provides a meaningful tailwind.

BE11:47am

During this period, HILS has completed two acquisitions.
The first, Engineered Endeavours Inc was acquired on 17 August 2018 out of Chapter 11 for $6.4m. This is only the assets and some employees. The business designs and manufacturers utility poles for the power distribution and wireless telephone markets and adds 52,000sqft of additional manufacturing capacity. The second, Composite Advantage Inc, was acquired on 5 October 2018 for an initial $10.6m. This business supplies fibre reinforced polymer products for infrastructure markets and complements the existing US composites product range and addressable end markets.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@Ethelred: a profit warning's when a company warns that market expectations for profits are too high.)

BE11:48am

The two acquisitions are not expected to materially contribute in FY18, so we leave our forecasts unchanged. We upgrade our FY19E/20E EPS, both by 1%, mainly reflecting the contribution from Composite Advantage Inc.

Ethelred and how does it fit with a company statement that it expects to meet previously stated FY profit estimates
Ethelred So did CNA issue a 'Profit Warning' this am?
MassimoJ Hi BE - anything on Majestic, if time?
BE11:50am

Wait ... wait .... wait ..... @Ethelred, can I quote something for you?

BE11:52am

BE11:53am

jaws BE thank you.
11:53 am
BE11:53am

The P in EPS stands for profit, right? So it's a warning.

BE11:53am

The end.

undefined
urgeview game, set and match
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Okay, so Majestic.

RAVER @BE p stands for per
PandaMan "Earnings Profit Share" ?
Ethelred Well CNA also said that they expect to hit their full year targets...
BT Great snark BE
Pharma @BE, apologies for being a pedant, the E stands for profit (earnings), and the P stands for "per"
BE11:55am

So, UK sales are rubbish. Again.

Ethelred So is a warning a matter of intention on the part of cna or interpretation on the part of those receiving the communication,
BE11:56am

(@Pharma: oh yeah! I'm an idiot. Heh.)

11:56 am
BE11:56am

EBIT of flat “at best” in the retail and commercial businesses.

Finlay And rightly or wrongly most companies don't give the EPS line as their profit guidance.
BE11:57am

Plus Naked Wines is needing more investment, which isn't really a surprise.

cheeckychappy @BE - I do like a good glass of red now and again...
BE11:58am

Less good news is that Naked's KPIs are going the wrong direction, so the idea that it's the Screwfix to Majestic's B&Q gets undermined as well.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

There are three key points we would make from these results:

BE11:59am

The cost of growth at Naked Wines is higher than we previously expected. These amounts to an additional £1m spend in FY18/19E and £2m more p.a. from FY19/20E, thereby dampening short term earnings expectations,

BE11:59am

We question why Majestic had such a touch first half. The weather should have played strongly to its benefit as typically the summer should account for c.35% of FY profits and considering the extended summer period (and of such high quality) Majestic should have been one retailer to benefit strongly – so we question why this was not the case. We note a tough market backdrop at Majestic Retail and Commercial leads to downgrades and lower earnings visibility into the peak trading period. A strong H2 is required, and it is debatable whether the current consumer sentiment is one for an overly festive Christmas period as it has been the past few years, and

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Key KPI’s at Naked Wines have gone backwards in the half which are not helpful in the context of increased spend and further increases in spend now expected.

BE12:00pm

Sales retention rate has fallen 270bps to 78% and estimated payback periods have fallen for both the customers acquired last year and in this half. For last year the company now estimate these are 4.5x [previously 4.7x] and for the customers acquired in this period these stand at 4.0x down from 5.1x in the same period last year.

BE12:00pm

These paybacks are calculated on an undiscounted basis, implying the real value being generated from investment is lower than what is reported, in today’s money.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We would also urge the company to disclose customer numbers as this limits the ability to add much value from an analysis perspective.

Soundbuy Is gin consumption denting wine sales........I know one or two folks who after a long day would have reached for a glass of red who now opt for a swift G&T or three.........
BE12:00pm

And here's what happens to forecasts.

Soundbuy Personally I have the gin as a chaser............
Finlay @Ethelred the standard interpretation is 10% below consensus. The question here is the line in the P&L you take. If the company says that EBIT will meet - and that's their preferred line - is it a warning if EPS misses?
BE12:01pm

We reduce our EBIT estimates by 25-30% across FY19-21E - [1] Management guide to an “at least flat EBIT from Majestic Retail and Commercial" this year. We note that H1’18/19 delivered a £600k decline YoY in EBIT so we take a prudent view and assume decline of £1.2m in EBIT relative to last year.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

This results in a £2.5m cut to our current year forecast and see very limited growth thereafter, [2] we amend our Naked Wines model to reflect the higher rates of investment as well as moderate our sales retention rate from 85% to 80%. Both have a short term and medium term impact on profits.

BE12:01pm

In FY’18/19E this results in a £1m cut to our EBIT and around £3.5m p.a. thereafter, (3) we also increase our central costs by c.£200k p.a. to reflect additional investment, and (4) our forecasts also reflect a working capital build of £5-8m of additional inventory into the UK in order to mitigate any potential supply chain Brexit disruption in March 2019. There is also a planned build of additional inventory to support future Naked growth, in the US in particular.

BE12:02pm

And Peel Hunt.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Management states that it’s ‘steady as she goes’ at Majestic right now. We’d say that this was a rather “glass half full” interpretation of the prevailing situation. Yes, Naked is making the expected progress, US partnerships are flourishing and investment spend will increase. However, the core retail business looks very fragile currently, with industry conditions extremely tough and no room for any price increases to be passed on to customers (which puts a lot of pressure on gross margins). It’s a chunky downgrade today (c15%) and whilst we understand the longer-term opportunity at Naked, we suspect the forecast might well keep falling in retail, something that the overall multiple will not be tolerant of. We move to Hold from Buy and take the target price down to 350p.

BE12:03pm

You'll remember Panmure arguing last year in favour of a Majestic breakup: https://www.ft.com...-93c5-648314d2c72c

BE12:04pm

Wouldn't be wholly surprised to see that idea reappear today.

Ethelred @Finlay dunno - aren't there some rules around profit warnings?
12:04 pm
undefined
MassimoJ Thanks for that BE, much appreciated
BE12:05pm

All this fun chat around profit warnings reminds me of my days doing the 7am RNS shift on news wires.

cheeckychappy @BE seems to be taking an inordinate amount of stick for no good reason today.
red i would say...the shares are down, hence folks are disappointed in something...
BE12:06pm

Generally speaking, it was the 10% rule. If company followers told us that the new guidance was 10% or more below the previous guidance on their preferred measure of profit, it was a warning.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

And if the company flack phoned up to complain that it wasn't a warning by their definition, we'd change it in the next take to "veiled profit warning".

urgeview Well having traded for the past 20years....cna was a warning , albeit not a bad one. Needless to say, I'm losing on a big short on it for now but such is life!!
BE12:07pm

That learned them.

BE12:07pm

Anyway, we're done for Thursday.

Lemmy Thanks Bryce
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
Tony Scott Thanks BE
12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Nothing to add on the Intu PUSU.

urgeview CheersBE
Finlay It's murky. Companies have to report any significant changes to expectations to the market asap, but there are no stipulations as to how much of a miss and what line of profit a company uses as its guide so far as I know. Most guides say 10% - as BE says - and mostly around EBIT
Soundbuy ta
Finlay thanks all
BE12:08pm

We've voiced the various conspiracy theories around this on the previous extensions and have no more clarity now than then.
